instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D6990: What is D6990? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input, can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.R7051: What is R7051? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7052: What is R7052? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.CHGR_ACOK: What is CHGR_ACOK? This is identical to SMC_BC_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.TPS51125: What is TPS51125? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1278 model Macbooks.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..
definitions.PM_SYSRST_L: What is PM_SYSRST_L? PM_SYSRST_L is a system reset signal present when it is low, _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be high for the system to exit reset mode & turn on properly. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.SMC_BATLOW_L: What is SMC_BATLOW_L? SMC_BATLOW_L refers to a power management signal that indicates a low battery condition. The "_L" suffix suggests that this is an active-low signal, meaning that it becomes low when the battery reaches a low voltage threshold..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
The customer said there was no liquid spilled this machine. I did end up seeing very small corrosion on <RESISTOR>R5072</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R5082</RESISTOR> so I replaced them but that looks like the only area I can see liquid damage.
When I plugged in the charger I was seeing a very dim flickering green light. Now there is no green light at all. I tried with another known working dc-inboard but still the same.

When I measure F6905 and hold the probe there the voltage is constantly changing from 15.9v to around 18v. The fuse measured fine.
Next I measured <CHIP>U6901</CHIP> and I got 0v on every pin. In diode mode I got a 0v short to ground on pin 5(<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>)
<DIODE>D6990</DIODE> and pin 4 of <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> measured around 17v.

L6995 was showing a short to ground in diode mode so I removed it to see which side the short was on and it was on Pin 2.
I measured the resistance on Pins 17/18/27/28 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and they were correct so I still went ahead and replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> but the short is still there.

What should I check next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: Inject 3V from external power supply and see what heats up. Infamous shorted cap is the one under the piece of foam next to the battery indicator connector.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
You were correct I replaced that component and the machine started up. Once I logged in the charger symbol showed 'battery is not charging' and the light on the charger stayed green. On the system information page it did show the battery as being installed and its cycle count.
I tried with another battery and still the same issue so I replaced <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR>/<CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> first then when that didn't solve it I replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> again.

This time the green light changed to orange with the battery plugged in but there is no fan spinning or anything. <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is there but <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is not. I measured F7040 in diode mode and it gives me a short to ground. 

Might this be an issue with <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: Remove F7040 and tell us which side of F7040 the short is on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
The short is on Pin 1.(ISL side)

I measured <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> in diode mode and I got shorts to ground on pins 1/2/3.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: Remove 6259 and check if short is gone, if ok replace with new 6259

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
Ok so a bunch of crap has happened.
I removed the 6259 and the short was still there so I removed <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/<TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> and the short was gone. I did as louis says and replaced the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>, and <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> altogether.

After replacing them the short was gone and when I plugged the charger(board only) in the green light came on but no fan spin but <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> was 12.6v. I was checking through the power rails and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> was there was <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> was not. Before I could check anymore rails the charger light went back to the dim green light and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to 0.18v .

On <CHIP>U6901</CHIP> <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is present but here is no <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>. There is no short to ground on <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>. <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is at 3.46v.

Is this a rabbit hole board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
Okay some more funny business happening.
I go to check <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL> and I see 3.4v so I check <CHIP>U6901</CHIP> and I get 3.4v on <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> and the 3.4v made its way to Pin 1 of <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>. Pins 4/5 of <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> also have 3.4v so I don't understand why the charger light is not bright green yet.

Update: I checked the resistance of <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> and it was showing somewhere in the 3 milliohms area which is way more than the 20 ohms it should be so I replaced it with one from a board that measured the proper resistance and when I put it on this board it is measuring 7 mohms.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
milliOhms, Ohms, MOhms. You throw around measurements and units that don't make sense. The only problem with this board was the shorted cap until you messed with the 6259. I have no idea what is wrong now and I cannot rely on your measurements either. ACOK is gone now it is back......
My vote is another dead or badly soldered 6259. I cannot diagnose if soldering and measurements are not reliable.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
Sorry about that. I meant MOhms.
But I checked the board again and I don't know if it cooling down had any effect but <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> is measuring properly and the green light is back on but there is no fan spin. I
I checked a few of the main rails. 
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> are present
<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> - missing
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> - missing
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> shows around 0.54v and slowly goes down

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: We need more information to solve <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> missing on a board with this. I am with duke that something is badly soldered here, signals that show up then don't show up like <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> point to poorly soldered <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
Okay I replaced the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> and I made sure to solder it on correctly. The fan spun so the s0 rails were working. I went to go plug the board into the machine and attach all the cables(HDD LVDS, etc) and when I plugged the charger in the light turned green but no fan spin. 
Again I went back and replaced the ISL and again the fan spun and I check and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> was 3.4v and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> was present. I waited about 30 minutes before plugging the charger in again and once more the fan didn't spin.

Could it be that when I am putting the ISL on something in the area is working temporarily from the heat?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: something in the machine is obviously causing this, go component by component and figure out what it is.my guess is fucked keyboard/battery indicator/trackpad.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: wait I don't understand how those things can cause it to work at one moment then stop working some time later. On the second time I replaced the ISL it was working with only the board plugged into the charger. I didn't plug any external cables into the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
Okay I did some reading of the system diagram to see where <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> goes and it led me to the <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP> and the missing voltages led me to more chips. I also see that some of these enable signals come from the PCH so I hope that is not the issue.

No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> or <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>.

<SIGNAL>PM_SYSRST_L</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 0v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> are both present.

<CHIP>U7200</CHIP> (<CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP>) (didn't want to list all 25 pins so I just picked the main ones)
Pin 1(entrip1) - 0v
Pin 2(vfb1) - 0v
Pin 6(entrip2) - 0.785v
Pin 13(en0) - 3.45
Pin 16(vin)- 12.53v
Pin 17(vreg5) - 4.94v
Pin 23(pgood) - 0v

<TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR>
1- 0v
2- 3.48v
3- 0.78v
4- 0v
5- 0v
6- 0v

<CHIP>U7941</CHIP>
1 - 3.5v
2 - 3.49v
3 - 3.48v
4 - 0v
6 - 3.31
7 - 0v
8 - 3.48v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
Here are some more measurements I got that lead me to believe there is an issue with <CHIP>U7940</CHIP> but I could be wrong.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS_FET</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>P5V_3V3_SUS_EN</SIGNAL> show 0v
<SIGNAL>P5V_3V3_SUS_EN</SIGNAL> comes from <CHIP>U7940</CHIP>.
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>,  and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_PWRCTL</SIGNAL> all have at least 3.3v but there is no output on <SIGNAL>PM_SUS_EN</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
Finally my own troubleshooting has paid off. 
I replaced <CHIP>U7940</CHIP> and now the board is working and it boots up.

Thanks for the help guys.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: The question here is how <CHIP>U7940</CHIP> was dying when it was inserted into case!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: What do you mean by 'inserted into case'?'
